description:
TEDI-London is a new degree awarding HE provider focused wholly on engineering. The TEDI-London
building is the first in the
development of a temporary,
modular, education and research
campus in Canada Water, developed
by British Land.

factsheet.heading: Construction
paragraphs: TEDI-London's campus building was designed and built in nine months by offsite construction company, Premier Modular.

The lightweight nature of the steel-framed offsite system allowed the campus building to be sited on the existing concrete base of a disused carpark. This avoided the need for intrusive deep pile foundations.

The site was sub-divided into four deliverable parcels set around a modular grid using Premier’s standardised 12m by 3m modules. Built offsite in the UK, the building itself took just six weeks to construct once the modular components had arrived on the site, minimising disruption to the local area.

factsheet.heading: Sustainability
paragraphs: In line with TEDI-London's values, the building boasts numerous features to improve its sustainability. Each module uses lightweight steel frame boxes clad with insulation and at the end of its life, the building can be reused on-site, relocated in its entirety or stripped and the materials recycled, contributing to the circular economy.
The modular approach to construction brought several important environmental benefits:
•	As with all Premier buildings, the offsite structure was manufactured generating zero waste to landfill.
•	The modular components will be dismantled for sustainable re-use or recycling when the Institute relocates to its permanent home.

Other environmental features include low energy LED lighting with PIR sensors, highly efficient heating and cooling using air source heat pumps and mechanical heat recovery, and Siberian larch cladding which can be re-used or recycled when the building is dismantled.

factsheet.heading: Usability
paragraphs: Currently, TEDI-London has taken an initial c. 15,000 sq ft of floorspace, including classrooms, breakout spaces and labs. The solution allows for rapid, incremental expansion up to 40,000 sq ft, which British Land will deliver in phases as the organisation grows.

On campus, everything has been designed to be flexible; furniture is reused around the building to meet different requirements and student feedback is gathered to ensure their needs are met within the space.

The building features a large double span exhibition, events, and cafeteria space, with a folding wall to divide the events space from the café when required. There are four large ‘makerspaces’ for practical learning, viewing galleries, smaller conference-style meeting and teaching rooms, a full-height glazed entrance, offices and student common room.

One corner of the building was extended to three storeys to add visual interest and to create a large roof terrace for social interaction and with views over the Rotherhithe peninsula. Services in the ceiling are exposed to allow students to understand the complexities of the building as part of their learning experience.
